International Restrictions:
*All travellers: Travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. There are a small number of exemptions for certain categories of traveller, including non-resident workers.
All travellers must present proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao. The last dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to arrival, but within the last 7 months. Travellers under the age of 12 are exempt, as are those with a medical certificate of unsuitability for COVID-19 vaccination. Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China who have travelled overseas in the 21 days prior to their arrival will also be denied entry.
Testing / screening on arrival: Macao has introduced a QR three-colour code system, which replaces the previous digital health declaration needed at border checkpoints and for entering public administration premises, casinos and other venues. The new code requires its users to confirm whether they have been in COVID-19 quarantine at home or in a government-run facility and consists of three colours: red, yellow, green. Visitors receiving red or yellow codes may be subject to testing, hospitalisation or restrictions on their movements.
*Quarantine requirements: Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or Mainland China, who have visited Hong Kong or Taiwan 21 days prior to arriving in Macao, must hold a certificate of a negative result for COVID-19 nucleic acid test performed within the past 24 hours and will need to go to a designated place for up to 14 days of medical observation on arrival in Macao.
Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or Mainland China, who have visited Mainland China 14 days prior to arriving in Macao, must hold a certificate of a negative result or a certificate of specimen collection for COVID-19 nucleic acid test issued within the past 7 days. The Macao Special Administrative Region Government has placed further restrictions on arrivals from specific locations within Mainland China.
Residents of Macao returning from most foreign countries (including the UK) must hold a certificate of a negative test result for COVID-19 nucleic acid test performed within the past 48 hours and will need to undergo up to 14 days of medical observation. Additional pre-departure tests are required for travellers from certain countries. You can find further details on quarantine requirements from the Macao Government Tourism Office. *If you’re fully vaccinated: Regardless of vaccination status, travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. There are a small number of exemptions for certain categories of traveller, including non-resident workers. You can find further information by visiting the Macao Government Tourism Board website. All travellers must present proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao.
*Proof of vaccination status: All travellers must present proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao. Paper certificates issued by the Macao Health Bureau and Hong Kong Department for Health are accepted as proof of vaccination. The last dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to arrival, but within the last 7 months. Travellers under the age of 12 are exempt, as are those with a medical certificate of unsuitability for COVID-19 vaccination.
*If you’re not fully vaccinated: Regardless of vaccination status, travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. There are a small number of exemptions for certain categories of traveller, including non-resident workers. All travellers must present proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao.
If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: You must hold a certificate of recovery proving at least two months have passed since the onset of disease, or since the first positive test to be allowed entry into Macao.
*Children and young people: Children aged 12 or under are exempt from vaccination requirements on entry to Macao. For all other requirements, children aged 17 and under are subject to the same rules as adult travellers.
*Transiting Macao: Macao’s mainland border crossing points have resumed normal service. Macao’s Barrier Gate checkpoint at the Zhuhai land border is operating between 6am and 1am daily. The Macao-Zhuhai checkpoint on the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is also operating between 8am and 10pm. Private cars are allowed to access these two border crossings. Transit services are suspended at Macao International Airport.
The Macao-Hong Kong checkpoint on the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is now operating between 10am to 8pm. All other crossings between Hong Kong and Macao have ceased until further notice.
*Exemptions: Application procedures for Foreign Nationals seeking exemption from entry requirements can be found on the Macao Government Tourism Office’s website.

Internal Restrictions:
*Public spaces and services: Macao has introduced a QR three-colour code system, which replaces the previous digital health declaration needed at border checkpoints and when entering public administration premises, casinos and other venues. The new code requires its users to confirm whether they have been in COVID-19 quarantine at home or in a government-run facility and consists of three colours: red, yellow, green. Visitors receiving red or yellow codes may be subject to testing, hospitalisation or restrictions on their movements.
The Macao SAR Government may impose COVID-19 restrictions at short notice. This may include regular COVID-19 testing for certain groups of workers. You should check the latest information on the Macao Information Bureau website. Bus services between Hong Kong and Macao, using the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge, recommenced a limited service on 8 May. Contact the service provider for the latest schedule.
If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
